params.text:
• Antimony (Sb) occurs naturally in rocks
  • Antimony also gets into the environment from human activities like mining and burning fossil fuels.
  • Inhaling antimony over a long period of time can hurt your lungs and make it hard to breathe.

• Arsenic (As) exists naturally in rocks
  • Arsenic also gets into the environment through human activities like industry and mining.
  • Eating, drinking, and breathing arsenic over a long period of time can lead to cancer, and it can heart your heart and kidneys.
  • The biggest source of arsenic exposure for people is through the food they eat.

• Barium (Ba) occurs in many different forms (called compounds) in nature.
  • Barium and its compounds are also used in human industries like mining and making insect and rat poisons.
  • Long-term barium exposure can hurt your kidneys.
  • Most people who are exposed to barium are exposed at work. You can also get exposed to barium by eating contaminated food or drinking contaminated water.

• Beryllium (Be) occurs naturally in rocks and soil.
  • Berrylium also gets into the environment when humans use it to make electronics and when humans burn fossil fuels.
  • Breathing beryllium over time can cause hurt your lungs and even lead to lung cancer.
  • When people work in industries that use beryllium, they get exposed to unhealthy amounts of it.
  • Other people are exposed by eating contaminated food or water or breathing contaminated particles.

• Cadmium (Cd) occurs naturally in the earth's crust.
  • Cadmium is also released when humans make dyes or batteries. These industries release a lot of cadmium into the air, water, and soil.
  • Breathing cadmium regularly over time can hurt your lungs and make it hard to breathe. It can also hurt your bones!
  • People are exposed to cadmium when they smoke cigarettes, or when they eat food that is contaminated with cadmium.

• Chromium (Cr) has some natural sources, most of it comes from human industries like making metal plates and tanning leather.
  • Exposure to chromium over time, even in low amounts, can cause cancer.
  • People who work in industries that use cadmium can end up with unhealthy amounts of it in their bodies. People are also exposed by eating contaminated food or drinking contaminated water.

• Lead (Pb) occurs naturally in the environment, but a lot of it is released into the environment by humans. This happens when humans burn fossil fuels and mine for minerals.
  • Lead is especially bad for really young children and pregnant people. It can harm the brains of babies while they're trying to grow!
  • The most common way people get lead in their bodies is by breathing dust that has lead in it, or drinking water with lead in it.

• Mercury (Hg) gets into the environment from human industries.
  • If you are exposed to mercury over a long time, it can hurt your stomach, nerves, and kidneys.
  • People get exposed to mercury by eating food with mercury in it and breathing air with mercury in it.

• Thallium (Tl) occurs naturally, but most of it in the environment comes from humans. That happens when people burn fossil fuels and make metal products.
  • Long-term exposure to thallium causes damage to your nerves, lungs, and kidneys.
  • People get exposed to thallium through contaminated foods, especially home-grown fruits and vegetables planted in soil with thallium in it.
